North Korea has had nuclear ambitions since its leadership under Kim Jong
Un’s grandfather, Kim Il Sung, who established the country in 1948.
North Korea’s capabilities have evolved over the years, with more than 100
missile tests since its first in 1984. The country conducted its first
intercontinental ballistic missile test in July 2017, and as of Sept. 3,
2017, it had conducted its sixth nuclear test.
Those tests have taken place under three generations of leadership. Kim

U.S. presidents have failed to make North Korea end its nuclear weapons
Former President Bill Clinton negotiated a deal in 1994 with North Korea
to provide it with two nuclear reactors and heavy fuel oil in exchange for
the country giving up its nuclear weapons program. That agreement failed.
